title.native: リトルウィッチアカデミア 魔法仕掛けのパレード
title.romaji: Little Witch Academia: Mahou-jikake no Parade
title.english: Little Witch Academia: The Enchanted Parade

description:
You can tell witch training is not going swimmingly for the young sorceresses Akko, Lotte, and Sucy—they face expulsion for screwing up one class too many, and their only way out is if they successfully organize their academy's annual parade through a nearby town. But when they stumble upon the momentous discovery that the objective of the parade is to humiliate witches and commemorate their past subjugation, Akko decides it is time for a change: It is time to show the world how fantastic modern witches truly are! However, with the other girls struggling to keep up with Akko's grandiose ambitions, and everything from mischievous boys to slumbering giants getting in their way, maybe pulling it off will require not only all the magical prowess the pupils of Luna Nova Magical Academy can muster, but also a miracle.

(Source: MAL Rewrite)

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Witch
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a witch.

tags.name: Primarily Female Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of female characters.

tags.name: Slapstick
tags.description: Prominently features comedy based on deliberately clumsy actions or embarrassing events.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Ojou-sama
tags.description: Features a wealthy, high-class, oftentimes stuck up and demanding female character.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Cute Girls Doing Cute Things
tags.description: Centers around female characters doing cute activities, usually with little to no emphasis on drama and conflict.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Primarily Child Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters below a high school age.

tags.name: LGBTQ+ Themes
tags.description: Prominently features characters or themes associated with the LGBTQ+ community, such as sexuality or gender identity.

name.native: コンスタンツェ・アマーリエ・フォン・ブラウンシュバンク＝アルブレヒツベルガー

node.description:
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉成曜) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoh_Yoshinari) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=yoh_yoshinari)

A Japanese animator, director and storyboard artist currently working at [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/). Yoshinari entered the anime industry through the influence of his older brother, [Kou Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102136/). Several of his early works were uncredited second key animation and in-betweens for his brother during high school. After leaving professional school, he applied to [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) and [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). Not receiving a response from Gainax, he joined Madhouse. Due to a misunderstanding, Gainax failed to process his application until three months later. Not wanting to explain, Yoshinari told Madhouse; "being an animator is too hard for me," and switched to Gainax.

At Gainax, Yoshinari had joined just after the closure of [Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water](https://anilist.co/anime/1251/). With nothing to do, he was immediately put onto visual development for the film [Aoki Uru](https://anilist.co/anime/21430/), although the film’s production was later broken off due to the studio’s financial state. Undoubtedly his breakout as an animator was just a few years later when he served as one of the lead animators in [Neon Genesis Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/30/). Yoshinari worked at Gainax until leaving for Trigger in 2011, a studio founded by fellow ex-Gainax members, [Hiroyuki Imaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/97349/) and [Masahiko Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/108023/). At Trigger he debuted as a director on [Little Witch Academia](https://anilist.co/anime/14349/).

Yoshinari is recognized by the way he represents volume and perspective using spheres, especially for smoke and explosions, as well as his character action in general. His characters often borrow traits from western animation, such as rectangular heads, low contrast shading, big eyes and angular lineart. He uses expertly timed smears, dramatic camerawork, and complicated background animation to convey dynamism. His movement is springy and tense, cleanly situated in the dominant cartoony style of ‘00s Gainax. He remarks [Nijitte Monogatari](https://anilist.co/manga/112385/) as one of his most important influences, with his artistic style particularly visible in his design work for [Tengen Toppa Gurren Lagann](https://anilist.co/anime/2001/) and Little Witch Academia.

Also a big fan of [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)’s, having done multiple short [animations](https://anilist.co/anime/123638/) based on his manga characters.

Married to producer [Naoko Tsutsumi](https://anilist.co/staff/150017/).

(Sources: Wikipedia, Anidb, Animators Wiki)

(Sources: Wikipedia, Anidb, Animators Wiki)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/tuka_trg)

After graduating from the Department of Art at Osaka University of Arts he joined Studio Ghibli as photographer and later transferred to Gainax, where he made his debut as director on some episodes of Evangelion.
    
He left Gainax in 2011 to found [Studio Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/Trigger) together with [Hiroyuki Imaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/97349/Hiroyuki-Imaishi) and [Kazuya Masumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/150019/Kazuya-Masumoto). He is currently the CEO of the company.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/yujikaneko)

Founder and representative director of Aoshashin.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/yujikaneko)

Founder and representative director of Aoshashin.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/96109118) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/porigoshi/)

Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/). Currently a freelancer, but has close ties to [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/). He also took part in the production of Steven Universe, an American cartoon. He worked as a storyboarder on the 107th episode of the series and the feature film which was released in 2019.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1515331173983330306)

Nishigori graduated from the Toei Animation Institute and joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) as an in-betweener but he rapidly distinguished himself as a key animator. He was inspired to enter the field because he liked [Hidenori Matsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/107672/) and [Takeshi Honda](https://anilist.co/staff/103303/)'s drawings.

His first major role was serving as character animation director for [Top wo Nerae 2! Diebuster](https://anilist.co/anime/1002/Gunbuster-2-Diebuster/), with the task of adapting [Yoshiyuki Sadamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/98158/Yoshiyuki-Sadamoto)'s character designs for animation. This experience led him to become one of the main character designers at the studio, designing the iconic characters for [Gurren Lagann](https://anilist.co/anime/2001/).

He left Gainax to have his debut as director on [The Idolm@ster](https://anilist.co/anime/10278/The-Idol-Master/), a personal passion project since he's a great fan of the series. Several Gainax staff followed Nishigori to [A-1 Pictures](https://anilist.co/studio/561/) and worked on the series, alongside staff from newly formed [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/Trigger).

In 2018 he directed his original project [Darling in the Franxx](https://anilist.co/anime/99423/), once again reuniting with his Gainax friends spread among [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/), Trigger and [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/).

More recently he worked as character designer and chief animation director for [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/)'s final Evangelion installment, [Evangelion: 3.0+1.0 Thrice Upon A Time](https://anilist.co/anime/3786/Evangelion-3010-Thrice-Upon-A-Time/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1515331173983330306)

Nishigori graduated from the Toei Animation Institute and joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) as an in-betweener but he rapidly distinguished himself as a key animator. This experience led him to become one of the main character designers at the studio, designing the iconic characters for [Gurren Lagann](https://anilist.co/anime/2001/).

[Instagram 1](https://Instagram.com/padua2812/) | [Instagram 2](https://Instagram.com/paduamoreiraantonio/)

Antônio de Pádua Moreira Santos, better known only as Pádua Moreira, is a Brazilian actor, voice actor and dubbing director.

__Non-Anime Roles:__
~!- Zazu (The Lion King)
- Darth Vader (2nd voice; Star Wars franchise)
- Michael Caine (Most of his movies)
- Razoul (Aladdin's Franchise)
- Lotso (Toy Story 3)
- Cornelius (Planet of the Apes Franchise)
- Balin (The Hobbit Movies)
- Alfred Pennyworth (Some Batman productions)
- Mustafa (Ratatouille)
!~
